questions.question: Primary purpose of a PR template is to:
options: Capture intent, scope, risk, and test plan for reviewers
questions.additionalContext: Templates standardize context so reviewers quickly understand change intent, risk areas, and validation steps.

questions.question: Risk labels on PRs should influence:
options: Depth of review, required approvals, and CI rigor
questions.additionalContext: Higher–risk changes warrant deeper reviews, more approvals, and stricter pre–merge checks.

questions.question: Non–blocking vs blocking feedback should be handled by:
options: Separating must–fix from suggestions with rationale
questions.additionalContext: Clear separation keeps velocity while ensuring critical issues block merges; suggestions can be queued.

questions.question: A practical SLA for reviews prioritizes:
options: Time to first response and time to decision
Longest possible review duration to catch everything
questions.additionalContext: Fast first response unblocks authors; time to decision keeps delivery predictable.

questions.question: Effective reviewer checklists emphasize:
options: Security, accessibility, performance budgets, and error handling
questions.additionalContext: Checklists target risk hot spots and keep reviews consistent across changes and teams.

questions.question: Pre–merge CI policies that improve quality include:
options: Optional tests to speed up merges
Required status checks (tests, lint, security) before merge
CI only after merge to main
questions.additionalContext: Required checks prevent regressions and enforce policy–as–code before changes land in main.

questions.question: Using draft PRs early primarily helps by:
options: Triggering early CI and gathering feedback on approach
questions.additionalContext: Drafts invite design feedback and CI validation earlier, reducing rework later.

questions.question: A healthy review culture encourages reviewers to:
options: Ask questions with rationale and offer alternatives
questions.additionalContext: Questions with rationale support psychological safety and better decisions.

questions.question: Design a PR template that encodes risk and validation info. Include sections, example labels, and how it maps to required checks.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Include sections: Context, Scope, Risk level, Test plan, Rollback plan. Risk labels drive required checks (e.g., high–risk requires security scan and two approvals). Provide examples and link to standards. Keep a checklist for security, accessibility, performance budgets, and error handling.

questions.question: Propose review SLAs and norms for a team handling mixed–risk changes. Show how to measure and improve them over time.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Set SLAs: time to first response ≤ 4 hours in working time; time to decision ≤ 2 days for typical changes. Label risk to scale approvals and checks. Track metrics (first response, decision time, change failure rate, developer sentiment). Run monthly retros, adjust templates and checklists, and coach on separating must–fix vs suggestions.
